headline: Pommes Purée (Rich and Creamy Mashed Potatoes) Recipe
description: If you like your potatoes rich and creamy instead of fluffy, the key is to work them more and add lots of butter and cream.

video.description: Don't want to fuss with mashed potatoes right before serving Thanksgiving dinner? Here are three ways to make them ahead of time and have them come out just as delicious. [Video: Vicky Wasik. Recipes: Daniel Gritzer, J. Kenji López-Alt]
video.name: 3 Ways to Make Delicious Mashed Potatoes in Advance

name: Pommes Purée (Rich and Creamy Mashed Potatoes) Recipe
keywords: holiday, mashed potato, potato, side, thanksgiving
recipeIngredient: 4 pounds (1.8kg) Yukon Gold potatoes, scrubbed, unpeeled
16 tablespoons unsalted butter (2 sticks; 8 ounces; 230g), melted
Up to 1 cup (240ml) low-sodium chicken stock (optional)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: In a large pot, cover potatoes with cold water. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce to a simmer. Cook until potatoes are tender and offer no resistance when poked with a paring knife. Drain and let stand until cool enough to handle.
Carefully peel potatoes, transferring potatoes to a large bowl as you peel them.

Pass potatoes through a ricer or food mill set over the now-empty pot or, optionally, the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. (For the absolute smoothest texture, work the potatoes through a drum sieve before proceeding; this is entirely optional and not required unless you're in a very fancy French restaurant kitchen.)

If using the stand mixer, whip on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase speed to high and whip until smooth, about 30 seconds longer; transfer whipped potatoes to now-empty pot and add butter, cream, and a generous sprinkling of salt. If skipping the stand mixer step, add butter to potatoes in pot along with the cream and salt.

Bring cream to a simmer, allowing butter to fully melt. Fold in hot cream and melted butter, stirring well to incorporate. Season to taste with salt and pepper. For even creamier potatoes, or for more savory ones, add additional cream or the optional chicken stock, pouring it around the mass of potatoes and bringing to a simmer before folding in. Keep warm until ready to serve.

review.reviewBody: All of my life my mother made the best mashed potatoes and she always used red potatoes. I use red potatoes or Yukon gold, NEVER NEVER NEVER russets, and I make fantastic mashed potatoes. Like my mother, I use evaporated milk, and that uses up the water that is left in the potatoes after boiling, and I also leave them on low heat with a cocked lid briefly to dry them out. So I essentially really vehemently disagree with this article.
I used to make these with the 14 tablespoons of butter per the recipe from Joël Robuchon. Yum
@Kenji, why no breadcrums? Question from a swede.

is the ricer really necessary when all we're really doing is beating the living hell out of the potatoes anyway?

my gf really likes those simply potatoes things, but they are expensive and i don't want cancer from the glue. does it require any special chemistry to make them revive like that in the microwave?

SharonL, I'm not a food scientist and Kenji can speak to this better than I can, but I believe the starches in potatoes are very gelatinous and gluey, and when getting cold the molecules don't separate as well and begin to stick together, forming a hard lump. They can be revived most times by adding back into a small pot with a dash of milk and/or butter at low heat, enough to bring it back to a creamy and smooth consistency.
